Hi C=E9dric,

What you wrote below would make more sense to me if typing wa=
s the
most time-consuming part of the development process for me and I ofte=
n
ended up in the situation where refactoring makes the tests I wrote
befor=
e invalid. Or refactoring invalid tests would take more time than
I felt I =
gained from the TDD process.

TDD for me is a thinking tool, it helps me so=
lve problems
incrementally and I often end up with simpler solutions than I=
 first
thought I would. Of course sometimes I arrive just where I thought I=

would with the complexity I thought I would have but I seldomly know
that =
in advance.

I agree with you that one should always question what one is d=
oing and
look for improvement in any situation.

/J

>  Here is a scenario =
I've seen happen fairly often:
>
>  Write test1
>  Write code1
>  Write tes=
t2
>  Write code2
>
>  Then a refactoring comes to mind and you realize you=
 don't need code1
>  and code2 any more, so you write code3, and suddenly, =
you find
>  yourself having to refactor (or throw away) both test1 and test=
2.
>
>  I was simply suggesting that sometimes, the following flow works be=
tter:
>
>  Write code1
>  Write code2
>  <realize a refactoring is possible=
>
>  Refactor code1/code2 into code3
>  <happy with the result, now we writ=
e the test>
>  Write test3
>
>  Net result:  two less tests to write.
>
